image.altText: King Charles is seen through the car window.

items.synopsis: Thousands of people have gathered along the procession route to catch a glimpse of King Charles III and Queen Consort Camilla ahead of the coronation. Follow live.

title.children: King Charles arrives at Buckingham Palace ahead of historic coronation ceremony

schema.headline: Live updates: Crowds arrive for King Charles III's coronation ceremony at London's Westminster Abbey

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Let's check out some other famous faces
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The coronation is still 1.5 hours away and yet Westminster Abbey is nearly at full capacity as guests continue to arrive.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Maggie Smith, Emma Thompson and more arrive
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Spotted any other famous faces in the crowd yet? Here's a quick compilation of the celebs who've arrived so far.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: King Charles arrives at Buckingham Palace
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: King Charles III has arrived at Buckingham Palace from Clarence House ahead of his coronation ceremony.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: King Charles promised a 'slimmed down' coronation, but the total cost is still under wraps
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: By Europe bureau chief Steve Cannane The palace has promised a "slimmed down" coronation. But is that what we will be seeing today? It you compare it to the 1953 coronation there with be about a quarter of the guests, a shorter ceremony and procession, but the costs will remain high. The government has kept the price tag a secret, but some estimates put it at £50-100 million. A lot of Brits are unimpressed that so much public money is being spent in the middle of a cost-of-living crisis. A recent YouGov poll found that 51% of those surveyed did not think the coronation should be paid for with taxpayers' money, 32% though it should, 18% said "don't know". Lauren Woodfine, a tattoo artist from Lancashire told me, "He's just becoming King, just put your hat on". Michael Glenn, the town crier of Morecambe, has a different view. "I understand that the cost of living is absolutely dreadful for everybody. But I think what it (the coronation) will bring to the country outweighs the cost."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Lionel Richie takes his place in Westminster Abbey
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: It was announced last month that Lionel Richie and Katy Perry would be among the lineup of stars to perform at Charles' coronation concert this weekend.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Police arrest republican leader ahead of coronation, group says
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: British police have arrested Graham Smith, leader of an anti-monarchist group Republic, ahead of King Charles' coronation, a spokesperson for the group said. Police did not confirm the arrest, saying they did not immediately name those arrested. A photo posted on Twitter showed Smith sitting on the ground surrounded by a group of police officers. An officer at the scene said three republican protesters had been arrested.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Who or what are we most excited to see tonight?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: I love the pomp and ceremony and looking out for the famous faces. - Rae Same, Rae! I'm keen to see all the coronation fashion from the royals, especially from Catherine, the Princess of Wales. Who or what are we most excited to see tonight? And how is everyone celebrating tonight? Let me know in the comments!

liveBlogUpdate.headline: We're on the ground outside Buckingham Palace
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Here's another quick update from our Europe correspondent Isabella Higgins, who is right in the thick of it. Royal fever is red hot down at Buckingham Palace. Crowds are coming in thick and fast, adorned in their best Union Jack-inspired clothing. It’s a sea of red, white and blue. They’ve come from near and far, young and old, coming together to see this spectacle. The military band can be heard rehearsing in the distance. These crowds are gripped with anticipation and excitement.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: 'No one does pomp and pageantry like the British'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: From Europe correspondent Isabella Higgins Sindy Viney (L) has travelled from the Central Coast in New South Wales to be at the coronation. "I love the ceremony … the pomp and pageantry, no one does it like the British." While camping out she's befriended Nina Hosking a local London resident who woke up at 4am to travel to Buckingham Palace. "My mother was here at the Queen's coronation, she's 88 and she wanted to be here today," she said. "She was 17 and slept overnight to see it … so I'm really here representing her and being part of a moment in history."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: WATCH: Julian Leeser says Coronation celebrates office above politics
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The Liberal MP says he thinks of Australia as having an Indigenous heritage, British foundation and multicultural character.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Emma Thompson is also in attendance
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: I've just spotted British actor Emma Thompson arriving at the coronation with her husband Greg Wise.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Nick Cave has arrived at King Charles' coronation
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: He's here! Earlier this week the Australian musician defended his decision to attend King Charles’s coronation. Writing in his online blog The Red Hand Files, Cave has explained his decision to attend had less to do with his political leanings and more to do with his love of pageantry. "I am not a monarchist, nor am I a royalist, nor am I an ardent republican for that matter," he wrote. "What I am also not is so spectacularly incurious about the world and the way it works, so ideologically captured, so damn grouchy, as to refuse an invitation to what will more than likely be the most important historical event in the UK of our age."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: How can I watch the coronation in Australia?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Live coverage and commentary started at 5pm AEST on ABC News, with the official ceremony starting at 8pm AEST. You can watch proceedings as they happen on ABC iview, and if you miss any of the action you can catch up post-event. I've also added the ABC live stream to the top of the blog, and of course I'll be bringing you all the action right here.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What time will Charles be crowned King?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The ceremony will officially start at 11am UK time today, May 6. For Australians that will be 8pm AEST tonight. While the ceremony will start at 11am, proceedings – including King Charles and Queen Consort Camilla's journey to the cathedral in a carriage – will kick off around 10:20am UK time, which is 7:20pm AEST .

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Welcome to the coronation of King Charles III
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Hello and welcome to our live coverage of the coronation of King Charles III, it's lovely to have your company. It's been 70 years since we witnessed the coronation of the longest-ruling monarch in British history — Queen Elizabeth II. Now, in just a few short hours, millions of people across the world will tune in to watch as her son, King Charles, is crowned the new monarch. Crowds have been gathering for days outside Westminster Abbey, and now thousands of people are lining the procession route hoping to catch a glimpse of Charles and Camilla. I'm Jessica Riga and, together with my colleagues, we'll be bringing you all the latest updates and reactions from London and around the world. So let's kick things off!

It's been 70 years since we witnessed the coronation of the longest-ruling monarch in British history — Queen Elizabeth II. Now, in just a few short hours, millions of people across the world will tune in to watch as her son, King Charles, is crowned the new monarch. image.altText: An image of King Charles III in front of a royal, patterned background with the words "Watch live" superimposed

items.synopsis: Follow all the pomp and ceremony from the royal coronation as it unfolds in London.

title.children: Watch our live coverage of King Charles III's coronation

image.altText: Bodhi Mani Risby-Jones paraded by Indonesian authorities in balaclava and jumpsuit

items.synopsis: Bodhi Mani Risby-Jones apologises in a press conference for attacking a man badly enough to hospitalise him and for "the embarrassment I've caused".

title.children: Australian admits to rampage in Indonesia after being paraded in prison jumpsuit

image.altText: Man in Istanbul

items.synopsis: Chinese holiday-makers say they want to come to Australia, but some travellers are having their tourist visa applications rejected.

title.children: 'They all thought I was joking': Chinese travellers surprised at Australian tourist visa refusals

image.altText: A young man smiles at the camera in a black and white image taken in a busy indoor location.

items.synopsis: University student Alex Shorey, who unknowingly ingested rat poison in Taiwan, thanks everyone responsible for helping him return to Australia, as he continues to recover in hospital.

title.children: Australian Alex Shorey speaks from hospital after ingesting rat poison in Taiwan

image.altText: A grey-headed flying fox hanging upside down in a cage.

items.synopsis: ACT Wildlife say grey-headed flying foxes are getting injured more regularly before they can make it to warmer climes as part of their seasonal migration.

title.children: Injuries often stop flying foxes from migrating from Canberra each year, so this group stepped in

image.altText: Office workers with woman in sleeveless top

items.synopsis: An audit of the Australian Public Service workforce has found that $20.8 billion was spent hiring tens of thousands of external contractors and consultants in the 2021-22 financial year, most of which saw the Liberal-National Coalition in power.

title.children: Public service audit reveals $20.8 billion outsourcing bill for last year of Morrison government

image.altText: King Charles III smiling in a crowd of people waving small United Kingdom flags

items.synopsis: To take the coronation seriously would be to try to make sense of an Australian prime minister pledging his allegiance to a crown that tried to exterminate my people. For people like me, absurdity may be the only sane response, writes Stan Grant.

title.children: When the Queen died, I felt betrayed by a nation. Today, I feel something quite different

image.altText: King Charles in a suit and sunglasses looks off in a green garden

items.synopsis: From his love for music to his passion for the environment, how well do you know King Charles?

title.children: Fancy yourself as a royalist? Try your luck with this King Charles quiz

image.altText: Ukrainian soldiers watch drone feeds from an underground command centre.

items.synopsis: Analysts say Ukraine has drones capable of reaching Moscow and Russia has increasingly claimed Kyiv's weapons have been getting closer to the capital. But the circumstances of the Kremlin strike remain "curious".

title.children: Is Ukraine's UJ-22 drone capable of carrying out a Moscow strike?

image.altText: Penrith Panthers' Stephen Crichton, wearing headgear and a pink jersey, grimaces during an NRL match.

items.synopsis: The Panthers get the win in their Magic Round clash with the Warriors, but the back-to-back premiers are definitely looking closer to the chasing pack than at any point since 2019, writes Jon Healy.

title.children: Penrith are the champs until someone comes and takes the trophy, but this year feels different

image.altText: Valynce Te Whare dives over for a try against the Sharks

items.synopsis: The Dolphins take on the Sharks at Lang Park in Wayne Bennett's milestone game 900 as coach, after the Panthers get over the top of the Warriors at Magic Round. Follow our ScoreCentre for the live scores and stats.

title.children: NRL Live: Dolphins' hulking rugby convert scores on debut in 30-point first half against Sharks

image.altText: Group of police officers at a Service NSW centre

items.synopsis: Mahmoud Salhab, accused of stabbing a Service NSW employee, remains in his cell as a court is told the 37-year-old is "not mentally in a stable position".

title.children: Man accused of stabbing Service NSW worker poses risk to prison officers, court told

image.altText: An Austrlain $2 coin has a picture of helicopter surrounded by bands of colour and the words "Vietnam war".

items.synopsis: Vietnam's communist government is demanding Australia cease issuing commemorative coins that, it says, show the flag of the toppled US-backed South Vietnam, a claim Canberra denies.

title.children: Vietnam government furious about release of Australian commemorative war coins

image.altText: Chalmers points in front of his face. He's standing in front of flags.

items.synopsis: Workers will have to wait another year before their wages outstrip the rising cost of living, according to Treasury forecasts to be released next week.

title.children: Real wages not tipped to rise for another year as living costs bite

image.altText: A woman leaving a meeting room in parliament

items.synopsis: Victorian Liberal MPs will vote on whether to expel controversial Victorian MP Moira Deeming after she denied plans to sue the party over her suspension.

title.children: Victorian Liberal MPs move to expel controversial colleague Moira Deeming

image.altText: A man in a suit and tie.

items.synopsis: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton now faces another by-election just weeks after defeat in the Melbourne seat of Aston.

title.children: Stuart Robert announces intention to retire from federal politics

image.altText: Bare branches covering a large beige building in the background.

items.synopsis: A high-risk paedophile who has not undergone treatment will be released from jail, with the Supreme Court finding there was a lack of appropriate rehabilitation programs for him in prison.

title.children: South Australia's Supreme Court grants release of high-risk paedophile who refused rehabilitation

image.altText: An Aboriginal woman wearing a black top takes a selfie photo.

items.synopsis: As an inferno engulfs a home on the main street of a port town, Margaret Dale Hawke walks out the front door. She had just murdered her own children.

title.children: How a mother became a murderer in a rich mining town in Western Australia's north

image.altText: Anthony Albanese and Jeremy Rockliff both holding AFL footballs.

items.synopsis: It's a pretty bad political look to have a huge budget surplus and to not have made some structural spending decisions in core Labor areas to address years of Coalition parsimony, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: The government's huge surplus and the optics of working-class Albo are complicating things ahead of budget night

image.altText: Ben Long tries to kick the ball as Harrison Petty wraps him up in a tackle

items.synopsis: Gold Coast play host to Melbourne looking to stage an upset, while Geelong's good form continues with a hard-fought win over Adelaide. Follow our live AFL ScoreCentre.

title.children: AFL live: Suns face Demons test at home, Cats make it five in a row against Crows

image.altText: An older man sits at an outdoor table looking sad.

items.synopsis: After losing his daughter Ciara to Claremont killer Bradley Robert Edwards, Denis Glennon's life was plunged into the abyss. A new book tells how he found the strength to claw his way back.

title.children: The murder of his daughter Ciara plunged Denis Glennon's life into an abyss, but he made it back

image.altText: Prince Harry walks down stairs wearing a suit and tie.

items.synopsis: King Charles's coronation was never going to be a straightforward thing. It takes a certain suspension of disbelief that might be pretty hard to achieve in post-colonial, post-Brexit, post-pandemic and post-Harry Britain, writes Virginia Trioli.

title.children: Two unanswered letters loom large on King Charles's big day — and only one is from Harry

image.altText: A man with brown hair is wearing a suit and a striped black tie. Behind him is a title screen with text on a map of the US.

items.synopsis: Fox News had asked lawyers for Dominion Voting Systems to investigate whether someone from its organisation leaked controversial internal messages from ousted Fox host Tucker Carlson that were provided in evidence for Dominion's recent defamation lawsuit.

title.children: Fox asks Dominion to investigate leaks of Tucker Carlson's controversial messages

image.altText: A car is seen crushed by a collapsed house after a strong earthquake in Suzu city, Ishikawa prefecture, northern Japan,

items.synopsis: A strong, shallow, offshore earthquake hits central Japan, killing at least one person and injuring more than 20 others, disrupting plans for holiday makers.

title.children: Strong magnitude-6.2 earthquake hits central Japan, killing one and injuring  20

image.altText: A woman holds a medical syringe and a small bottle labelled "Coronavirus COVID-19 vaccine"

items.synopsis: The World Health Organization emergency committee first declared that COVID represented its highest level of alert more than three years ago, on January 30, 2020.

title.children: WHO declares COVID-19 is no longer a global emergency, a major symbolic step towards the end of the pandemic

image.altText: A young man sitting on the beach staring at the ocean.

items.synopsis: When her son Jazpa couldn't focus at school, Sam Pinnell thought she was a bad parent. A diagnosis of foetal alcohol spectrum disorder changed that.

title.children: A foetal alcohol spectrum disorder diagnosis at seven changed Jazpa's life. Now he wants to lift the stigma

image.altText: An Australian male bowler pumps both his fists as he celebrates an Ashes wicket.

items.synopsis: Having missed out on selection in the initial squad for the Ashes, Michael Neser puts on a swing bowling masterclass to claim a hat-trick for Glamorgan. Watch the footage here.

title.children: Overlooked Neser topples English Test stars with hat-trick that has to be seen to be believed

image.altText: Two uniformed individuals overlooking ocean in New Caledonia from military plane

items.synopsis: For the past fortnight, Australia has taken part in an emergency training drill led by the French military in New Caledonia, as the two countries try to put the cancelled submarine deal behind them.

title.children: Australia and France take part in huge military exercise after tense couple of years

image.altText: A front-on close-up of a crocodile laying on a muddy river bank.

items.synopsis: The first fatal attack in more than two years reignites debate about rising crocodile numbers in Queensland, but researchers say removing them from waterways is unlikely to prevent attacks on humans.

title.children: Rising crocodile population in the spotlight but there is 'no need for any culling'

image.altText: Donald Trump glances down, his face in a tight frown, sitting between two men in suits

items.synopsis: A video deposition in Donald Trump's civil rape trial has been released and shows the former US president denying the allegation and mistaking an image of his accuser, E Jean Carroll, for his former wife, Marla Maples.

title.children: 'She's not my type': Court releases Donald Trump's deposition in civil rape trial

image.altText: A red football sits on the grass next to Hobart Cenotaph.

items.synopsis: Images of Hobart's proposed stadium, and how it will visually impact on the nearby Cenotaph, are released — but will it be enough to sway the RSL, who have dug in opposing the location?

title.children: The government says the Cenotaph won't be shaded by Hobart's new stadium — is it enough to convince the RSL?

image.altText: Tanya Hosch stands before an array of media microphones. She's holding and AFL Indigenous round Sherrin football.

items.synopsis: The AFL confirms nine football fans have been banned from attending games for life, while a further five are being investigated for racially abusing players as the league cracks down on vilification.

title.children: 'They are not welcome': AFL bans footy fans indefinitely amid crackdown on racism

image.altText: A young man and woman sit amid a row with a light yellow coloured dog

items.synopsis: Chloe and Jered have swapped their inner-city lifestyle to join a growing number of micro farmers, sowing the seeds of happiness while providing fresh produce to some of the country's top restaurants.

title.children: 'We've never been happier': Search for a better life sprouts new generation of small-scale farmers

image.altText: A Black woman holds a sign with Writers Guild of America on Strike written on it as she stands in a crowd.

items.synopsis: Writers created Tony Soprano, Don Draper and Shiv Roy. Now they've walked off the job, partly because they fear something fundamental will be lost if Hollywood allows itself to become a wasteland of AI-generated stories.

title.children: Hollywood writers are on strike over an AI threat that some are warning is coming for you next
